definition:
Let $a, b \in {\mathbb{C}}^n$. The set
$\ell := \{a + b z \mid z \in {\mathbb{C}} \}$ is called the [*complex
line*]{}.

A complex line is a holomorphic complex affine imbedding of
${\mathbb{C}}$ into ${\mathbb{C}}^n$ so that if $f$ is holomorphic, then
$z \mapsto f(a + b z)$ is also holomorphic. That is the complex
structures of $\ell$ and ${\mathbb{C}}^n$ are compatible. Hence not
every two dimensional real affine space is a complex line.

Let $a, b_1, \ldots, b_k \in {\mathbb{C}}^n$ such that
$b_1, \ldots, b_k$ are linearly independent over ${\mathbb{C}}$, then.
The set
$$\{a + \sum_{j=1}^k b_k z_k \mid z_1,\ldots,z_k \in {\mathbb{C}} \}$$
is called the [*complex affine space*]{}.

[9]{} Steven G. Krantz. [**]{}, AMS Chelsea Publishing, Providence,
Rhode Island, 1992.
